facts.text: Appeals numbered 283 to 295 of 1951 were filed in the Supreme Court under article 132(1) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION. Cases Nos. 283 to 295 of 1951. Appeals under article 132  1  of the Constitution of India from the judgment

facts.text: High Court of Allahabad delivered judgment and decree dated 10th May 1951 in various writ applications and miscellaneous cases.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and decree dated 10th May, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad  Malik C.J., Mootham, Chandiramani, Agarwala and Bhargava J.J.  in Writ Applications Nos. 23, 25, 3330, 3329, 3331 and 3332 of 1951

facts.text: Another High Court judgment and order dated 9th July 1951 by Sapru and Agarwala JJ in Writ Application No. 3403 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: and from the judgment and order dated 9th July, 1951, of Sapru and Agarwala J.J in Writ Application No. 3403 of 1951. 1058 The facts that gave rise to these appeals and petitions are stated in the judgment.

facts.text: Appellants in most cases are owners and proprietors of extensive landed properties in Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in most of them are owners and proprie- tors of extensive landed properties in the State of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Some appellants are holders of estates in Oudh under taluqdari sanads granted by British Government.

anchor.surface_text: Some of them are holders of estates in Oudh under taluqdari squads granted to their ancestors by the British Government.

facts.text: H.H. Maharaja Paramjit Singh of Kapurthala holds estate in Oudh guaranteed under article XII of Pepsu Covenant of Merger.

anchor.surface_text: H.H. Maharaja Paramjit Singh of Kapurthala, appellant in Appeal No. 285 of 1951, is the holder of an estate in Oudh, the full ownership, use and enjoyment of which was guaranteed to him by the Government of India under article XII of the Pepsu Covenant of Merger.

facts.text: Appeals Nos. 291 to 295 preferred by religious institutions holding endowed properties.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals Nos. 291 to 295 of 1951 have been preferred by religious institu- tions holding endowed properties.

facts.text: United Provinces Legislative Assembly passed resolution on 8th August 1946 accepting abolition of zamindari on payment of equitable compensation.

anchor.surface_text: On 8th August, 1946, the United Provinces. Legislative Assembly passed the following resolution -- 1059 This Assembly accepts the principle of the abolition of the zamindari system in this Province

facts.text: Zamindari Abolition Committee appointed and made report in July 1948.

anchor.surface_text: A companymittee was appointed to give effect to the resolu- tion and to prepare the necessary scheme. It made its report in July, 1948.

facts.text: Bill introduced in United Provinces Legislative Assembly on 7th July 1949.

anchor.surface_text: A Bill was introduced in the United Provinces Legislative Assembly on the 7th July, 1949, was referred to a Select Committee which made its report on 9th January, 1950

facts.text: Uttar Pradesh Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act (U.P. Act I of 1951) received President's assent and came into force on or about 25th January 1951.

anchor.surface_text: It was subse- quently passed by the Legislative Council and after having received the assent of the President came into force on or about the 25th January, 1951.

facts.text: Section 4(1) provides that all estates in Uttar Pradesh vest in State free from encumbrances by notification.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  1  of section 4 provides that as from such date as the State Government may by numberification declare, all estates situated in the Uttar Pradesh shall vest in the State free from all encumbrances.

facts.text: Section 6: rights, title and interest of intermediaries in estates vest in State free from encumbrances upon notification under s4.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 enacts that subject to certain very minor exceptions, upon the publication of a numberification under section 4, the rights, title and interest of all intermediaries in every estate

facts.text: Intermediaries entitled to compensation at eight times the net assets in Compensation Assessment Roll.

anchor.surface_text: The intermediaries whose rights, title and interest are thus acquired become entitled to receive companypensation at eight times the net assets mentioned in the Compensation Assessment Roll

facts.text: State Government to pay rehabilitation grant to intermediaries paying land revenue not exceeding Rs. 10,000 on graduated scale.

anchor.surface_text: The Act further provides that the State Government shall pay to every intermediary other than a thekadar, whose estate or estates have been acquired under the Act, a rehabilitation grant on a graduated scale provid- ed that the land revenue payable by such an intermediary does number exceed Rs. 10,000.

facts.text: Bill was pending in legislature on 26th January 1950 when Constitution came into force.

anchor.surface_text: This Bill was pending in the legislature of the. State on the 26th January, 1950, when the Constitu- tion came into force and this circumstance makes article 31  4  applicable

facts.text: In Balrampur Raj case, actual income of Rs. 1,42,000 reduced to Rs. 10,000 under Act provisions per affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: According to the affidavit filed in the Balrampur Raj case, actual income of Rs. 1,42,000 that the owner receives at present, works out to a sum of Rs. 10,000 under the provisions of the Act

facts.text: Culturable waste forms twenty per cent of entire area of estate.

anchor.surface_text: Culturable waste which forms twenty per cent. of the entire area of the estate, trees, several lakhs in number, water channels and irrigation works etc.

facts.text: Pepsu Covenant of Merger dated 5th May 1948 guaranteed Maharaja's Oudh estate as private property.

anchor.surface_text: By article 12 of the Covenant of Merger dated the 5th 1077 May, 1948, entered into between the Rulers of the States number companyprised in the Pepsu Union

facts.text: Oudh annexed in February 1856; taluqdars reinstated after mutiny; status by Oudh Estates Act I of 1869.

anchor.surface_text: the taluqdars were absolute owners of these holdings at the time of the annexa- tion of Oudh in February, 1856, that subsequently the Brit- ish Government under the directions of Lord Dalhousie

facts.text: Allahabad High Court dismissed writ petitions on 10th May 1951 and certified under art 132(1).

anchor.surface_text: By a judgment of a Full Bench of the Allahabad High Court delivered on 10th May, 1951, the petitions were dismissed. The High Court, however, certified, under article 132 1

facts.text: Zamindari Abolition Committee report submitted in August 1948.

anchor.surface_text: That companymittee submit- ted its report in August, 1948, making various recommenda- tions which have been summarised by Mr. S.K. Dhar

facts.text: Bill received President's assent on 24th January 1951.

anchor.surface_text: After having been passed by the U.P. Legislature the Bill received the assent of the President on 24th January, 1951.
Appeals under article 132  1  of the Constitution of India from the judgment and decree dated 10th May, 1951,

issues.text: Whether the impugned Act was validly enacted.

anchor.surface_text: The main questions for consideration in these appeals are the following -- Whether the impugned Act was validly enacted. Whether the acquisition of properties contemplated by the Act is for a public purpose.

issues.text: Whether the acquisition of properties contemplated by the Act is for a public purpose.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the acquisition of properties contemplated by the Act is for a public purpose.

issues.text: Whether the delegation of power in the various sections of the Act is within the permissible limits.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the delegation of power in the various sections of the Act is within the permissible limits.

issues.text: Whether the taluqdari properties held under sanads from the British Government can be the subject-matter of acquisition.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the taluqdari properties held under sanads from the British Government can be the subject-matter of acquisition.

issues.text: Whether the properties of the Maharajah of Kapurthala in Oudh could in view of article 12 of the Pepsu Union Covenant be acquired under the Act.

holdings.text: The impugned Act is protected by Article 31(4) as the Bill was pending in the legislature on 26th January 1950 when the Constitution came into force.

anchor.surface_text: This Bill was pending in the legislature of the. State on the 26th January, 1950, when the Constitu- tion came into force and this circumstance makes article 31  4  applicable to all these cases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bill history shows it was pending despite prorogation per Article 196; complete answer to compensation challenges.

holdings.text: Article 31(4) is a complete answer to contentions regarding Article 31(2).

anchor.surface_text: Be that as it may, article 31  4  is a complete answer to all these contentions, as held by me in the Bihar appeals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: References Bihar appeals; Bill pending validates Act against Art 31(2).

holdings.text: Provisions of Articles 31A and 31B completely shelter the Act from Part III challenges.

anchor.surface_text: Further the provisions of articles 31-A and 31-B completely shelter this law from any attack based on any of the provisions of Part III of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Express constitutional protection for estate acquisition laws with Presidential assent.

holdings.text: The acquisition is for a public purpose as it aims at agrarian reform, elevating tenants, and destroying zamindari system.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, legislation, which aims at elevating the status of tenants by conferring upon them the bhumidari rights to which status the big zamindars have also been levelled down cannot be said as wanting

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public purpose elastic, defined by inclusion/exclusion; aligns with State policy and Directive Principles.

holdings.text: Delegation of power in sections like 6(e)(g) and 68 is within permissible limits.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the delegation is within the permissible limits and does not amount to delegation of essential legislative power.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principles laid in Act; details like interest rates to rules.

holdings.text: Compensation provisions are not illusory; payable on vesting with interest.

anchor.surface_text: But from those facts the conclusion cannot be drawn that the provisions as to compensation in the Act are illusory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Net assets basis includes whole estate; ss 27,28,65 make payment obligatory; debts deductible but not discretionary.

holdings.text: The Act does not constitute a fraud on the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Having negatived the contentions of Mr. Das, I cannot for the same reasons accept the contentions of Mr. Dhar as sound.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior laws pre-Constitution; no colorable device.

holdings.text: Taluqdari properties under sanads can be acquired; Crown cannot derogate principle does not bar legislature.

anchor.surface_text: the matter seems to have been set at rest by the decision of their Lordships of the Privy Council in Thakur Jagannath Baksh Singh v. United Provinces... Parliament... is not debarred from legislating so as to vary the effect of a Crown grant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Privy Council precedent: legislature competent within scope.

holdings.text: The impugned Act respects guarantees in Pepsu Covenant; Kapurthala estate acquirable as private property with compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned Act has fully respected the Covenant of the 5th May, 1948, inasmuch as it has treated the Oudh estate as the private property of the Maharaja... and it is on that basis that it has proceeded to acquire it on payment of compensation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Treats as private property, pays compensation; no breach of Art 362.

holdings.text: Article 363 bars jurisdiction over disputes regarding Pepsu Covenant.

anchor.surface_text: article 363 of the Constitution bars the jurisdiction of this Court from going into this question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: GoI party to covenant as guarantor and concurring party.

holdings.text: Properties of religious institutions can be compulsorily acquired.

anchor.surface_text: A charity created by a private individual is not immune from the sovereigns power to compulsorily acquire that property for public purposes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compensation based on net income; no immunity for dedicated property.

holdings.text: No obligation to provide compensation implicit in entry 36 List II read with entry 42 List III.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given by me in the Bihar appeals I cannot accept this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects petitioner argument per Bihar precedents.

holdings.text: Bill does not lapse on prorogation; pending on 26 Jan 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Section 73 of the Government of India Act, 1935, and article 196 of the present Constitution provide in unambiguous terms that a Bill pending... shall not lapse by reason of the prorogation.

holdings.text: All appeals dismissed; no substance in any contentions.

anchor.surface_text: The result therefore is that there is no substance in any one of the appeals and I would accordingly dismiss all of them.

precedents.cited_proposition: private property cannot be taken for strictly private purposes at all, not for public uses without a just compensation and that the obligation of contracts cannot be abrogated or essentially impaired

precedents.citation: Thakur Jagannath Baksh Singh v. United Provinces 1 ... 1 1946 F.C.R. 111

anchor.surface_text: the decision of their Lordships of the Privy Council in Thakur Jagannath Baksh Singh v. United Provinces 1 . At page 119 of the report it was observed as follows-

precedents.case_name: Thakur Jagannath Baksh Singh v. United Provinces
precedents.cited_proposition: Parliament, whether Imperial, Federal or Provincial, in the absence of express prohibition, is not debarred from legislating so as to vary the effect of a Crown grant; the Crown cannot deprive a legislature of its legislative authority by making a grant of land
precedents.cited_holding: no court can annul the enactment of a legislative body acting within the legitimate scope of its sovereign competence

precedents.citation: Sweet v. Rachel 1 ... 1 4x L. Ed. 188 at pp. 196-97
